The music usually sucks, I mean writing and the whole deal. The lyrics usually suck harder and the requisite twang in the singing to make it country and not sh*tty pop music with a background fiddle and steel guitars makes me want to puke.

 It is definitely a matter of taste. There are most assuredly 'posers' in country music, just as there are in any other genre, but I happen to love country music. I don't like every artist out there, but try to listen with an open mind. It is about the music. Guitars, fiddles, banjos and pianos (stringed instruments). I like bluegrass ("o brother Where Art thou" changed the face of bluegrass) simply because of its purity, and Alison Krauss has an angelic voice. But I also like mainstream artists like Toby Keith becasue he really sounds good, and I like what he has to say. If you don't believe country artists are good musicians, listen to Brad Paisley play guitar. if you still don't believe it, well, I guess we'll never agree...
 
 One of my biggest reasons for liking country is the fact that I can understand what the heck they are saying!!! emoticon_xagree

I don't think there is a style of music that I reject out right.
 
 I am definately a rock fan first and foremost, but I also have country, blues, classical, show tunes, celtic, punk, and metal in my cd collection.
 
 However, to discuss country on its own merits - I like it, but I definately want it to sound like country. Too much contemporary country is trying to meld into mainstream pop and ends up sounding like ****. I prefer the likes of someone like Dwight Yokam who keeps his twang. THAT is part of the idea.
 
 Country is about the aches and pains of of every day people in every day life. The melodies are simple and honest. It should not be deep, controversial, or political. It is also not world's innovator. Country is not and does not belong on the edge of anything.

But I also like mainstream artists like Toby Keith becasue he really sounds good, and I like what he has to say.

They are rock bands, with some punk influence - and Blink and the Ataris are way too Clear Channel friendly foir my taste. The Dixie Chicks make the slightest comment that they are ashamed to be from the same state as the president, and everyone is all mad. There were boycotts from the stations.  Well, 'Courtesy of the Red White and Blue' is not a political song. It's just a cowbow way of saying "hey, you screwed up attacking us and we are going to kick your a$$!" That's what that is. 'American Soldier' is just a song supporting our troops. His political views are: "I don't know much about politics, there are people who we vote for that are, hopefully , alot smarter than me about things like that. I don't necessarily support everything they do, but I do support them in the effort." To his credit, he backed off of his fight with the Chicks once he realized how ridiculous it was. Seems to me he is just someone who is proud to be an American, who appreciates the sacrifice of our troops.
 
 The Dixie chicks are great musicians, but they l;ost my support when they bashed the president in front of a foreign (French) crowd, right in the middle of a war! I don't care what your opinion is, but (and I'm talking about entertainers here) keep it to yourself and just make music!

 Well, saying you are proud to be American is neither supporting nor disagreeing with the president. To say, in a foreign country, to foreign nationals, that they are ashamed of the president (or that he comes from their state) is certainly one way to gain popularity in said country. Of course I support the right of the Dixie Chicks to spew whatever garbage they want to. I feel (note, this is my opinion and I have no proof) that they were doing so in order to sell a few more records to some people who don't give a **** about their politics, anyway! I will say that they are sellouts and if they are ashamed of the President, they are welcome to say so, just don't get upset when your REAL fan base- the ones from your own  country- are turned off by your statements. that's what happened to them. By the way, their song "Travelling Soldier" was awesome. I still say that they are great musicians- they sing and play and, from what I've heard, entertain very well. But they made their political bed and really have no one to blame for their misfortune than themselves. Most country music fans are quite patriotic, I guess.

At no time does toby Kieth say in any of his songs, "We'll put a boot in your A$$, 'cause we support the president heart and soul." Well, saying you are proud to be American is neither supporting nor disagreeing with the president. To say, in a foreign country, to foreign nationals, that they are ashamed of the president (or that he comes from their state) is certainly one way to gain popularity in said country.
 

 But also, Toby Keith was talking about how proud he was to be an American to gain popularity as well. It also wouldn't gain popularity to go against the opinion of most Americans. I believe this was honest opinion. I believe this too. Bush is a discrace to our country in foreign affairs. He goes to the UN asking for help but also says he's just going to attack anyway. This puts out a horrible image and they were saying that that's not really what America or even Texas is really like.
 
 

 Of course I support the right of the Dixie Chicks to spew whatever garbage they want to. I simply said they are a bunch of liberal wenches, that talked trash about our president during a time of war. Toby never did that. He never said he supported or opposed the president.  How in the world do you consider supporting our troops as political? Do you want them to fail in their assigned task? If you want them to succeed and come home safely, aren't you supporting them? Does that make you political? As for the Pres. I am a military man. Have been for fifteen years. It is my JOB  to support the president. That doesn't mean I agree with everything he asks me to do, nor does it make me a political animal. If you disagree with my statement, then I guess we just have a very different opinion of what is and is not political support.
 
 As far as music from the 60's and 70's, I guess I have to conceed that point. The music from that era was completely based on politics...
 I guess I just get tired of entertainers using their celebrity to promote their own brand of politics.

As for the Pres. I am a military man. Have been for fifteen years. It is my JOB  to support the president. That doesn't mean I agree with everything he asks me to do, nor does it make me a political animal.
